awd_titl_txt: Broadening Participation in Coastal and Estuarine Sciences: A Workshop of the 25th Biennial Conference of the Coastal and Estuarine Research Federation; Mobile, AL - November 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
I. The Coastal and Estuarine Research Federation (CERF) has articulated full organizational commitment to broadening participation in coastal and estuarine science. CERF developed Rising TIDES (Toward an Inclusive, Diverse, and Enriched Society) as a comprehensive program for enhancing the diversity and inclusion of our scientific society and CERF conferences. The overall goals of this program are to promote opportunities for all underrepresented and underserved minorities while cultivating a culture that actively engages and leverages diversity throughout our organization. Rising TIDES intentionally affirms and promotes the value of diversity in all forms, including differences among individuals in racial and ethnic backgrounds, genders, sexual orientations, nationalities, and physical abilities.

II. Broadening participation in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) is widely recognized as critical to the science and engineering enterprise. There is still a wide gap in U.S. STEM educational attainment between URM individuals and whites and Asians, and coastal and estuarine science faces similar gaps in URM representation. In recognition of this gap and to incorporate
fundamental change in the way the CERF community supports and addresses the individual needs of all members, CERF seeks funding to support diversity and inclusion efforts at its 2019 Biennial Conference in November 2019. Specifically, these efforts include: (1) enhance URM student professional development throughout a two-conference cycle, including cohort building, mentoring, and participation
in a URM-focused workshop, scientific sessions, and other conference activities; (2) build the capacity of CERF to achieve DEI objectives through a workshop open to all attendees, and through additional learning opportunities throughout the conference; and (3) ensure broad engagement of the CERF community by infusing DEI throughout the conference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
Increasing the participation of marginalized and minoritized groups in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics is essential to sustaining the nation's capacity for innovation and discovery. Despite this fundamental truth, the gap continues to widen between the overall number of college degrees granted in marine sciences and degree attainment from underrepresented groups. These trends have particularly disturbing implications for the nation’s estuaries and coastlines, where much of the minority population in the U.S. resides: the diversity of the individuals studying, managing, and protecting these important natural systems does not reflect the diversity of those who live there.

 

The Coastal and Estuarine Research Federation (CERF) is a multidisciplinary organization committed to advancing scientific understanding and wise stewardship of estuaries and coasts. Through the Rising TIDES (Toward an Inclusive, Diverse, and Enriched Society) Conference Program, CERF:

  • provided 15 students from underrepresented backgrounds with professional development while inspiring and supporting them along their chosen career paths in coastal and estuarine science;
  • provided attendees at the CERF biennial conference with opportunities to learn about and reflect on diversity, equity, and inclusion in our disciplines;
  • enhanced its capacity to broaden participation of minoritized and marginalized groups within the organization; and
  • raised awareness of issues surrounding diversity, equity, and inclusion within the wider coastal and estuarine science community.

 

Through this project, 14 students and their mentors were able to attend and participate fully in the 25th Biennial CERF Conference in November 2019. A student-centered workshop provided an opportunity to learn strategies for success in coastal and estuarine science professions, and assisted students and mentors in developing a support network.  Students and mentors were encouraged to engage with each other throughout the conference, including a program-sponsored welcome and close-out event.

 

In addition, there were activities throughout the biennial conference that highlighted diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) issues for attendees.  CERF members and conference attendees were educated on identifying and addressing implicit bias through a pre-conference workshop. CERF hosted a conference-wide Inclusion Luncheon event that allowed for discussion and reflection on DEI in the marine sciences. DEI was infused throughout the conference, including participation of diverse plenary speakers, and issuing plenary remarks on the importance of DEI by CERF leadership. After the conference, CERF hosted a webinar on hiring and recruiting for equity.

 

CERF’s plans for broadening participation were synthesized within the more general context of diversity in coastal and estuarine science in an open access Perspectives Essay in the journal Estuaries and Coasts, which has a global reach.  Harris et al., “A Socio-ecological Imperative for Broadening Participation in Coastal and Estuarine Research and Management,” used CERF’s efforts as a case study for this essay.
